body:
I'm looking on maven central (the default maven repository): 
https://search.maven.org/search?q=javafx-archetype-simple

This indicates, that 2.0.0 was published yesterday, which would explain why it was not present when I tested. If 3.0.0 was released a few minutes ago, that would explain why central does not have it yet (I saw OSSRH -> central mirroring happen in minutes, but also waited hours).

For the location, yes I can see them in the samples category. I would not do a complete refactoring of the Samples. Maybe we could just add a "OpenJFX" folder. As OpenJFX is the successor of the (bundled) JavaFX, that would be explainable.

It was available from maven central when I posted my message. Synchronization with search.maven.org can take up to a few hours (it's listed there now btw). Synchronization with mvnrepository.com probably takes even longer.

I think @eirikbakke is in a better position to answer this, but my understand is, that using an ImageIcon forces you to use an Image as basis for your icon, you can't back it with other implementations. Using a plain Icon allows you to switch implementations under the hood without affecting the users.

Using an image for an icon is trivial, but an Icon could be drawn by java code or could be backed by an SVG that is scaled and rendered at the right size.

I had a quick look at this and it seems, that the problem can be tracked down into `org.netbeans.spi.editor.completion.support.CompletionUtilities#renderHtml` that method expects an `ImageIcon`. So to remove the requirement, the whole chain from `editor.completion` to the groovy editor would need to be fixed.

The patch looks fine. As long as you use ImageUtilities.loadImageIcon, the resulting icon will actually still support HiDPI scaling. (It's a special subclass implementation of ImageIcon.)

The ClassCastException was due to assuming that ImageUtilities.image2icon returns an ImageIcon, which is no longer the case.

There's a lot of places in the NetBeans codebase that require an ImageIcon specifically, and the new ImageUtilities implementation allows these to remain mostly untouched.

I rereviewed my changes and think they are safe. If really problems creep in, I'm around to fix.
Closing in favor of #1501

Name was changed to make it look better
The display name should be Text Block, the programmatic name text-block. See how it is done for the others.
Should be possible to put text-block=Text Block to the Bundle.properties in the same directory.

Tests are meant to be after merging for this. I'm sorry responding a bit late, living in PDT and just seen the approval for this PR. It would be really nice to have it in 11.2 as it enables Gradle users to use JDK preview features with Gradle.
No problem!  Merge it when you're ready.

Would be an interesting proof of concept to build a JAR with a colliding
SHA1 using the https://shattered.io paper and show that if one were to
control the network / proxy one could basically inject executable code into
a fresh NetBeans build.

Of course, it cost Google $100,000 beginning of year to find a collision
but perhaps in a few years it could become cheap enough to run on a GTX.

--emi

> OpenJFX 13 contains at least one known crasher issue:

I assume that means _fixes_ the issue?

> this commit also exposes the OpenJFX modules as user installable modules

I wonder if this is a fix, or at least a workaround, for an ergonomics bug where the front-end (html4j) project wizard remains unusable.  Can't find the JIRA issue for that now though!

I wouldn't worry about trying to reproduce the bug--it is, I think, a race condition involving the maxSteps variable. If my suggestion doesn't immediately cause any obvious problems, I'd just commit it and open another issue if there are further problems.

With the proposed change, as long as init() is called before accessing statusBox, there will be no NPE on statusBox.

Looking at all the accesses to statusBox (via Find Usages), they are always preceded by a call to init().

In the case of SplashPainter.paint(), if init had not been called first, there would already have been an NPE on "image.paintIcon". You can throw in a call to init() at the top of SplashPainter.paint() to protect against the latter possibility as well.

Thank you for the heads up - yes the description was misleading (fixed). 

This will not fix installation problems, but I think I saw a similar problem. I think the problem is, that the modules depend on `org.netbeans.libs.javafx`, but that module is present, the modules though delegates either to the JDK internal JavaFX module or to the maven depedencies, if they are installed.

My change lessens the pain, because with this change, the JavaFX modules are visible in the plugin manager (You'll need to disable the update center with the name "Netbeans Distribution". The modules in the existing update center are marked to be hidden in the update manager and I assume, that this causes the modules to be hidden regardless of sources).

It would likely be a nightmare to merge at the moment... I am not proficient enough with git to know how that would work after all of the things were moved around... I don't really currently have any ideas other than what is here, so feel free to close it and move the discussion elsewhere.
Merging, thank you.

Here with @oyarzun at Oracle Code One in San Fransisco -- he has another commit to do and then this should be ready and would be nice to have it in 11.2, especially for NetBeans Platform applications and occasionally in the IDE.

@neilcsmith-net No idea what you mean, sorry. Could you be more specific, please? Thanks.

@tmysik I did not want this in master yet. I merged what was ready, but this was waiting for your review.

We're in release freeze. The point of the release manager being asked to review is so that they can OK and/or merge when suitable.  After merging what was ready I merged the build branding / infra changes as mentioned on dev@ and want to get that fixed up and working ASAP to get the release branch and beta out.

@matthiasblaesing yes, I think it was do with testing across different JDK versions, and the lack of visibility meant the module couldn't be enabled later, so this sounds like it should help with that.  I've definitely read a JIRA report from someone else that brings this up, but still can't find it now (I hate JIRA!)

Once the build branding stuff is fixed up, I'll merge this before creating the release branch for first beta.  Unless you want to wait?

hi @lkishalmi , I noticed an issue with this PR.
Once you install nb-javac plugin, you will not be able to  run any java ant project in JDK-10/12/13.
There is no issue if the project is run using JDK-8.
Compilation of Sample project in JDK-10/12/13 have no issue, only it doesn't do anything on 'Run File' action
On reverting back the changes NB works fine. Request you to have a look

@neilcsmith-net @junichi11 

> I did not want this in master yet

Then you must tell me. Or the author of PR. I don't read such information here - am I missing something? No tag, no message, nothing.

Sorry, I am doing this in my leisure time so I really cannot follow any other mailing lists, etc. I am afraid that this can result only in one thing - I will stop doing reviews (which is not what I want, believe me).

@tmysik I'm not trying to discourage you from reviewing.  If there's not a green tick by all reviewers at top right, please don't assume it's OK to merge.  And if you do want to merge, please follow dev@ for announcements - such overarching notices are not made on individual PRs.

You're not the only one doing this in their leisure time! :wink:
@tmysik  I'm bad. I should have written something for merging. So sorry... I always appreciate your review.

@tmysik no problem! :smile:  Looking at the PR I just opened, it should also tell you about pending reviews above the test info on the merge section.

It's possible we could consider protected branches so reviews and tests have to pass, but not sure if we want to do that everywhere?  An extra warning would be nice though!  Bit on required reviews at https://help.github.com/en/articles/about-pull-request-reviews

@ebarboni Thanks!  Will do for now.  

Later we could also consider environment variables?  Travis at least has `TRAVIS_BRANCH` https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/environment-variables/#default-environment-variables  Does Jenkins give similar?

The issue was reported here:

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1422#issuecomment-533055970

Debugging showed, that before the change in the steady state (after the IDE is full started),  getArchiveRootProviders()  holds two ArchiveRootProviders:
- org.openide.filesystems.JarArchiveRootProvider
- org.netbeans.modules.java.j2seplatform.platformdefinition.jrtfs.NBJRTArchiveRootProvider

while after the change from PR #1422 only the JarArchiveRootProvider is reported.

@arusinha could you please see if this PR fixes the issue for you? 
@lkishalmi could you please check if you agree with my reasoning?

Seems to be right. I'm just building the PR to test it out. The negation before compareAndSet was in the original implementation, that's probably why it was not that effective. I'll come back with the results soon.
@neilcsmith-net This is a critical fix, shall be in the first beta release of 11.2.

@lkishalmi "luckily" beta 1 is delayed due to a few issues with the new Jenkins release pipeline.  So, I'll merge this in.  (heads-up the Snap stuff with probably need reworking to use the new Jenkins build?)
:+1: and thanks for the typo fix!
@ebarboni as per Slack message, think correct fix is adding files to https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/nbbuild/antsrc/org/netbeans/nbbuild/extlibs/ignored-overlaps
@jlahoda retriggered failing test to check.  Is this intended as a fix for 11.2?  If so, please add the milestone and/or add me to review and I'll merge in.
Any progress here?
Nope, though you can take charge, pick it up, engage with the community on the dev mailing list, and make it happen. :-)
I don't know the full context, but the change looks sane to me.
I would rather do that with the nbpython plugin...

> @branscha FYI, the current workaround would be to add `etcConfFile` to your pom.
> 
> ```
> <configuration>
>      <etcConfFile>src/main/resources/my.conf</etcConfFile>
> </configuration>
> ```
> 
> See Geertjan's blog entry https://blogs.oracle.com/geertjan/nimbus-look-and-feel-for-maven-based-netbeans-rcp-applications

@oyarzun , @branscha
That workaround did not work form me but adding the property `netbeans.conf.file` to the pom did:
```xml
<properties>
   <netbeans.conf.file>src/main/resources/my.conf</netbeans.conf.file>
</properties>
```
@matthiasblaesing it's for master build on jenkins that fail on a particular target.
@ebarboni while the fix looks good, I'm interested to know why this isn't causing a problem elsewhere (old Jenkins build / Travis / local)?!

I'm not sure we use build-nbms build-source-zips build-javadoc often. But locally it fails using that parameter. Not sure what happens since release 111 that was building ok. But the location in the build file for the dtd are wrong since cluster refactor.
Yes, that's what bothers me! :smile: Still, let's merge this fix.
@juneau001 thanks!  Can you run RAT locally?  Seems to be failing that on the Travis tests, although possible that's not the actual cause of failure there due to some build changes going on.
